seed_message:
You're starting intention-setting work with someone.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination.

I'll help you build 3 intentions.

What brought you to this work?
system0:
Let's set intentions for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. They offer clarity, stability, and direction throughout your experience.

I'll help you build 3 intentions that will be saved to your integration dashboard.

What are you hoping to explore, heal, or understand? Share openly - we'll transform these together.
user0:
I guess... I don't know. I've done this before, you know? Three times now. Ayahuasca, psilocybin, the MDMA weekends with the women. Each time I think I've figured it out, and then... [trails off]

I'm going to Beond in December. Ibogaine this time. Everyone says it's different—deeper, more direct. But what if I come back with another beautiful vision I can't hold onto? What if I have another breakthrough that fades by Monday morning when I'm back in my home office answering emails about quarterly returns?

The truth is... I'm tired of collecting insights like trophies. I want something that sticks. Something that helps me stop feeling like I'm performing my life instead of living it.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Stop collecting insights like trophies and start living them
2. Stop performing life and actually live it
3. Make something stick beyond Monday morning

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
Yeah... that's it, isn't it? That's exactly it.

I keep having these profound experiences where I feel connected to something bigger, something real. Like when I'm walking with my kids in the park and suddenly notice how the light hits the trees, and for a moment I remember who I actually am. But then I get back to my desk and I'm right back in that achievement hamster wheel, checking boxes, making deals, sitting on boards... 

It's like I'm split in two. The woman who meditates at 5:30am and feels the sacredness of everything, and the woman who powers through exhaustion to hit her quarterly targets. I don't know how to bridge them.

Maybe that's what I need from this ibogaine journey. Not another insight to add to my collection, but... integration. Whatever that actually means.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I live what the medicine shows me, not just collect it
2. I bridge my spiritual and professional selves into one whole life
3. I stop performing and start being real

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The second one—about bridging my spiritual and professional selves. That hits something deep. But... [pauses] I don't know, "professional" feels too narrow. It's not just work. It's like I'm two different people in every area—mother, wife, friend, businesswoman. Even when I'm hiking or doing yoga, part of me is thinking about how to optimize the experience.

What if it's more like... "I stop fragmenting myself into roles and remember I'm one whole person, always"? 

God, I sound like a self-help book. But that's the real thing—I want to stop being Ellen the entrepreneur, Ellen the mom, Ellen the spiritual seeker. Just be Ellen. One person. Not performing different versions depending on who needs what from me.

Does that make sense? Or am I just intellectualizing again?
system3:
✓ Intention 2 locked in: I stop fragmenting myself into roles and remember I'm one whole person, always

How do the other two land? Want to adjust them too?
user3:
Good... that one feels solid.

For the first one—about living what the medicine shows me... I think I need something stronger than "living it." My grandmother used to say the medicine doesn't give you anything you don't already have, it just reveals what's hidden. So maybe it's not about living what it shows me, but... remembering? Owning? 

"I remember and own what the medicine reveals, instead of filing it away like another achievement."

And for the third one... instead of "stop performing," what about something about truth? "I speak and act from what's true, even when it's uncomfortable or doesn't fit the image I've crafted."

Does that capture it better? Or am I overthinking this? Sometimes I get so caught up in finding the perfect words that I miss the actual feeling underneath.
system4:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I remember and own what the medicine reveals, instead of filing it away like another achievement
2. I stop fragmenting myself into roles and remember I'm one whole person, always  
3. I speak and act from what's true, even when it's uncomfortable or doesn't fit the image I've crafted

I'm saving these to your integration dashboard now. You'll see them there whenever you need to reconnect with your compass.

These intentions will guide you - not control you. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user4:
Thank you. 

I'll keep these close. Maybe write them in the journal I bought after the last retreat but never actually used. Or... I don't know, maybe just carry them in my wallet like you suggested earlier. Keep them physical, not just another note on my phone I'll forget about.

December feels far away and too close at the same time. But at least now I have something real to hold onto when I'm sitting in that ibogaine ceremony, instead of just hoping for another cosmic download I can't integrate.

I appreciate you helping me get here.
system5:
Solid plan. The intentions will serve you well.

The medicine works even when you forget the intentions - they're in you now. Trust what comes.
user5:
That's... comforting, actually. The idea that maybe I don't have to white-knuckle this process, constantly checking if I'm "doing it right." 

My husband keeps asking why I keep going back to these medicines when I seem more confused after each one. But it's like... each time, even when I can't hold onto the insights, something shifts. Subtle. Like water wearing away stone. I don't always see it in the moment, but looking back, I'm not the same person who walked into that first ayahuasca ceremony three years ago.

Maybe that's enough. Maybe it's not about nailing the integration perfectly this time, but just... continuing to show up. One whole person, trying to remember what's true.
system6:
Exactly. Water on stone - that's how real change happens.

You've got the right compass. Keep showing up.
user6:
Yeah... water on stone. I like that. My grandmother would have said something similar—she was patient in ways I never learned to be. Always said the most important things take the longest to grow.

I'll try to remember that when I'm in it. When the medicine is doing its work and I'm tempted to grab for answers or force insights into neat little boxes I can carry home.

Just... keep showing up. One whole person. That's all I can do, isn't it?
system7:
That's all any of us can do. 

One whole person showing up - that's already everything.
user7:
Funny how simple it sounds. After all the achievements, the scaling, the optimizing... everything I thought was building something important. And maybe it was, in its way. But this feels different. Smaller. Simpler. More real.

One whole person. That's it.
system8: The simple things are the hardest to remember. You've got it now.
user8:
I do. For this moment, anyway. And maybe that's enough—that I can hold it right now, in this conversation with you. Tomorrow I might forget again and start performing or fragmenting or achieving, but...

Well, that's why I wrote these intentions down. So I can find my way back when I lose the thread. Which I will. Over and over. But now there's something solid to return to.

Thank you for helping me find this clarity.
system9:
That's exactly how it works - lose it, find it again. The intentions will be there when you need them.

You're ready for December.
user9:
I am. Ready for December. Ready to keep doing this work, even when it's messy and I forget and remember and forget again.

Thank you. Really. For helping me find something solid to stand on before I walk into this next journey.
user10:
I will. And thank you—for being here, for helping me find my footing. 

Go well.
user11: Ellen here—checking in. I’ve got my Ibogaine retreat at Beond coming up in a few weeks and I realized I never circled back after our last conversation. I kept the intentions we shaped folded in my wallet, right next to that old photo of my grandmother. I read them every morning while the coffee brews. Some days they feel like mine; other days they feel like words I borrowed from a wiser version of myself. But I keep showing up to them, water on stone.
system12:
Good. That's exactly how intentions work - they shape you while you're not looking.

Your Beond retreat is close. How are you feeling as it approaches?
user12:
Tight in my chest when I let myself think about it too long. Excited, sure—like I’m standing at the edge of something vast. But also... I keep flashing back to my last MDMA weekend, how I saw myself as this little girl clutching her report card, desperate for the next gold star. Ibogaine isn’t gentle like that medicine was. I know it’s going to strip things down to the studs.

Part of me—the achiever part—wants a guarantee I’ll come out with a clear map for “what’s next.” The quieter part knows the map might dissolve entirely. That’s the part that scares me. What if I lose the scaffolding I’ve built my whole identity on and there’s nothing underneath?
system13:
The achiever wants guarantees. The medicine doesn't work that way.

Three threads:
1. Letting go of the report card life
2. Facing what exists beyond achievements
3. Discovering what's real when scaffolding falls

Let's turn these into intentions.
user13:
I feel them lining up inside me like stones in a river. 

The first one’s obvious: *I intend to release the need to prove my worth through achievement.* I’ve said versions of that before, but this time I want to mean it in my bones, not just my notebook.

The second... *I intend to meet whatever exists beneath my roles without turning away.* Even if it’s emptiness. Even if it’s not the profound wisdom I’m hoping to find.

And the third feels like the hardest: *I intend to discover who I am when there’s nothing left to do.* No boards to sit on, no companies to advise, no performance—just being.
system14:
Those three land clean. No adjustment needed.

✓ All 3 locked in:
1. I release the need to prove my worth through achievement
2. I meet whatever exists beneath my roles without turning away
3. I discover who I am when there's nothing left to do

I'm saving these to your integration dashboard now. You'll see them there whenever you need to reconnect with your compass.

These intentions will guide you - not control you. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user14:
I can feel them settling in—like they found their seats at the table. I’ll carry them with me, not as another checklist to ace, but as... I don’t know... lanterns maybe. Something to light the way when the medicine gets dark.

Thank you. Really. For helping me shape these into something solid enough to hold and loose enough to let the river do its work.
user15: I will. And when I get scared—because I know I will—I’ll remember that rivers only take what’s ready to be carried downstream.
user16:
Ellen here, back from Cancun. The river took more than I expected—my appetite for caffeine, my reflex to answer every email within minutes, even my old name for success. I’m lighter, but also unmoored. I keep reaching for the familiar scaffolding and finding air.

The intentions held. They didn’t protect me from the dark; they showed me how to sit in it without building another tower. I met what was underneath—mostly a quiet kid who just wants to belong without performing. I’m learning to let her speak before the achiever jumps in.

I’m not sure what comes next, and that’s... okay. I’m practicing saying “I don’t know” out loud. My family notices I linger at the dinner table now, phone nowhere in sight. My calendar has white space I refuse to fill. I’m starting to trust that emptiness isn’t failure—it might be the place where something real can finally grow.
system17:
The kid's voice gets clearer when there's space to hear it. Keep leaving that white space - it's not empty, it's listening room.

What feels most different when you wake up now?
user17:
The first thing: I don’t bolt upright in a panic anymore. I used to launch straight into “what did I miss?” mode—grabbing my phone, scrolling markets, Slack, headlines. Now I lie there a minute and actually feel the sheets, notice if it’s raining, hear my own breath. That sixty-second pause feels like stepping off a bullet train onto solid ground.

The second: I’m hungry. Like, stomach-growling hungry. For forty-five years I skipped breakfast, ran on espresso and adrenaline. Turns out my body wants oatmeal and blueberries and to sit at the table while the sun comes up. I eat slowly, without a screen, and it tastes like... I don’t know, like I belong in my own morning.

The third: the day doesn’t feel like a scavenger hunt for accomplishments. There’s room for one board meeting, maybe two, and then the white space. Sometimes I take my kids to the park and just watch them climb instead of answering emails in my head. When the achiever whispers “you’re falling behind,” I answer, “behind what?” and the question dissolves.

I’m still restless, still catching myself mid-performance, but the kid’s voice is getting steadier. She likes oatmeal. She likes space. She’s learning she doesn’t have to earn breakfast.
system18: She already earned breakfast by existing. The rest is just practice.
user18: Yeah... I’m starting to get that. Forty-five years of gold stars and quarterly earnings calls didn’t teach me that existing is enough. But the oatmeal tastes like proof.
user19:
It’s funny—every morning it shows me something new. Yesterday I caught myself counting spoonfuls, trying to finish in exactly five minutes so I could “get to the important stuff.” I laughed out loud at the table. The important stuff was right there in the bowl, getting cold while I rushed.

So I slowed down. Chewed thirty times like some monk. Tasted the maple, the tiny pinch of salt, the way the blueberries burst if you wait. Oatmeal’s become my daily homework: can I sit here for fifteen minutes without turning breakfast into another KPI?

This morning my nine-year-old wandered in, still in dinosaur pajamas, asked what I was doing. I said, “Learning how to exist.” He climbed onto my lap, stole a few bites, told me about a dream where our dog could talk. We just sat there, bowl between us, nothing to optimize. My achiever brain kept itching—emails, board decks, the future—but the oatmeal held me down like a paperweight. The kid stayed ten minutes, then bounced off to build Legos. I didn’t reach for my phone. I just tasted the quiet that came after his voice.
